response.answer_text: I personally use Premiere Pro by Adobe to edit all of my videos, for work and for personal projects. It’s a fairly cheap and easy software to use, unfortunately you cannot buy it outright but you can get full access to it for $19.99 USD a month. If you do more complicated and in depth YouTube videos with graphics and audio effects, a must-have is Photoshop, Audition, and After Effects, all created by Adobe. You can get access to the whole Suite of Adobe software for $52.99 USD per month. If you are regularly editing large productions, it’s a very much worthwhile investment. If you are just starting out and are testing the waters for making YouTube videos, here are some options: If you are editing on Mac OS with a Macbook, or any kind of iMac, the editing software iMovie comes free with any MacOS computer. You can have multiple audio and video tracks, some built in effects and transitions, and the ability to place text on screen. It’s great for getting the feel of editing, but once you start to put together more complex videos it gets a little limited. If you see it as a worthwhile investment, the step up from iMovie is Final Cut Pro X, a $299 USD editing software specific to Apple products. It’s very powerful and allows you to do much more advanced edits with a full color grading suite, the ability to import transitions and graphics, create videos with custom resolutions, and much much more. If you are editing on Windows, a great free option is DaVinci Resolve. There is a “Studio” version that costs $299 USD, however the free version is more than enough for basic video editing. The color grading suite is one of the best in the industry, and it’s a very simple yet effective layout, with the ability to edit resolutions up to 8K. Hope this helps, if you have any more questions feel free to drop them below and I’ll see what I can do.

Content is King The type of software that you use doesn't really make a difference. This means that you can use Final Cut Pro 7 or X, Adobe Premiere Pro, Avid, Sony Vegas, iMovie, Windows Movie Maker, Youtube's editing software or don't even edit. If your content is compelling enough, you will have no problem getting views.  If you want a more professional look, it comes down to more of the lighting and audio quality as well as the camera and editing techniques used. The more professional softwares certainly lend themselves to facilitating creativity but once you are at the prosumer level of software, it has more to do with where you like your tools, how you like your windows arranged or Mac vs. PC. They all have subtle differences and there are plenty of websites and videos dedicated to the arguments but you'll ultimately have to try them out yourself to find what you like best.  If you are still looking to go a step further, you should get into motion graphics software like After Effects, Cinema 4D, Maya, Smoke, Nuke, etc. Adding motion graphic intros, lower thirds or even just textural effects can really make your videos pop. Similarly, look into color correction and grading with DaVinci Resolve.  I've switched over from FCP to Premiere and After Effects a few years ago after finding myself hating FCP X. I use a 2015 27" iMac with 32gb of ram and lots of plugins for the lots of programs I use! The best advise I can give you is : just keep making videos and don't ever stop. The more the better. Work with lots of people and try to learn from every experience, even when you get frustrated.
